items.title: What if patterns ADDED instead of multiplied?
items.content:
You'd get: Ralph (2x) + Hooks (1.5x) + Subagents (2x) = 5.5x
Why this undersells: Patterns remove friction that was limiting EACH OTHER.
Hidden insight: The multiplication IS the synergy. If you're not multiplying, you're stacking wrong.

items.title: The irreducible triple stack
items.content:
Minimal Triple+: Ralph + Hooks + CLAUDE.md
Essential: External state + automation + shared context
Everything else: Optimization for specific use cases.

items.title: Boris Cherny: 100% AI code in production
items.content: Claude Code creator uses 5-10 parallel sessions with shared CLAUDE.md. "I haven't written code in months." This is what triple+ enables.

items.title: Why multiplication happens
items.content:
ROOT: Each pattern has a ceiling
-> Ralph ceiling: manual formatting, context pollution
-> Hooks remove manual formatting
-> Subagents prevent context pollution
-> Ralph ceiling raised
-> Higher ceiling + automation = multiplicative effect

items.title: Triple+ Stacks = DevOps Pipeline
items.content:
Individual tools -> CI/CD pipeline
Manual tasks -> Automated flows
One developer -> Team velocity

If you've built a DevOps pipeline, you understand why components multiply.

items.title: All stacks share INV-003: External state > internal memory
items.content:
Unhobbled: Files for persistence
Creator: CLAUDE.md across sessions
Production: Git worktrees per agent
Compounding: progress.txt archives

Same invariant, different implementations.

items.title: How stack complexity fails
items.content:
2 components: Debuggable, traceable
4 components: "Which layer broke?"
6 components: "Is it hooks or subagents?"
All components: "Burn it down, start over"

Add complexity gradually. Always have a "strip to basics" fallback.

items.title: The Stack Selection Dilemma
items.content:
Unhobbled: Maximum power, maximum complexity
Creator: High quality, high cost
Production: Cost-efficient, setup-heavy
Compounding: Long-term value, slow start

Match stack to project lifecycle, not ambition.

items.title: Stack selection depth
items.content:
Beginner: "Which stack is best?" -> Start with Creator
Intermediate: "When to use each?" -> Match to project type
Advanced: "Can I combine?" -> Yes, stacks compose
Staff: "What's the minimal?" -> Just what removes YOUR friction
Expert: "Custom stack?" -> Extract patterns, build your own

items.title: Creator Stack + Compounding Learner
items.content:
Works: Parallel sessions + cross-run archives = institutional memory across branches.
Danger: Archive per session or merged? Merging archives loses session context.
Recommendation: Session-specific archives, periodic human synthesis to master learnings.md.

items.title: @EricBuess: The Unhobbled philosophy
items.content: "Remove all the guardrails. Let Claude work at full capability. The stack handles safety through automation, not restriction." This mindset produced the 6-component power user setup.

items.title: Stack ROI over time
items.content:
Week 1: "This setup is taking forever"
Week 3: "First autonomous overnight run"
Month 1: "I'm shipping 3x what I did before"
Month 3: "This is just how I work now"

Don't judge stack ROI until month 2.

items.title: If you skip the 5-week ramp-up
items.content:
IF: Deploy full Unhobbled stack week 1
THEN: Something breaks (it will)
THEN: You don't know which component
THEN: Debugging is impossible
FINALLY: Abandon stack, go back to vanilla

The fix: One component per week. Verify before adding more.

items.title: What if you used one stack for everything?
items.content:
You'd use: The Full Stack for all projects
Why this fails: Prototyping doesn't need Security First. Side projects don't need enterprise compliance.
Hidden insight: Stack selection IS architecture. Match stack to project constraints.

items.title: At 10+ stacks, patterns emerge
items.content: After trying multiple stacks, you start seeing which components YOU actually use. Your personal "minimal effective stack" emerges from elimination, not addition.

items.title: If the matrix doesn't fit your case
items.content:
Small projects? -> Single pattern, no stack
Exploratory work? -> Just Claude, no automation
Budget-critical? -> Budget Maximalist only
Quality-critical? -> Quality Obsessed only

items.title: Why 5 weeks, not 1
items.content:
ROOT: Each component has failure modes
-> You can't debug what you don't understand
-> Understanding requires running it in production
-> Production problems take days to surface
-> 1 week per component = minimum viable understanding
-> 5 components = 5 weeks minimum

items.title: When setup cost flips to payoff
items.content:
Week 1-3: Net negative (learning overhead)
Week 4: Breakeven (automation starts saving time)
Week 5+: Net positive (compounding returns)

THE INFLECTION: ~Week 4
Projects shorter than 4 weeks don't justify stack setup.

items.title: Roadmap = Gym Program
items.content:
Week 1 (hooks) = Learn form
Week 2 (parallel) = Add light weight
Week 3 (automation) = Progressive overload
Week 4 (advanced) = Complex movements
Week 5+ (optimization) = Periodization

Skip weeks = injury. Slow down to speed up.

items.title: How fast can you move?
items.content:
New to Claude: 2 weeks per phase minimum
Intermediate: 1 week per phase
Advanced: Can compress weeks 1-2
Expert: Can parallelize some phases
Power user: Still shouldn't skip validation

items.title: If you run parallel agents on same branch
items.content:
IF: Two agents modify same files
THEN: Race condition on commits
THEN: One agent's work gets overwritten
THEN: Corrupted state in next iteration
FINALLY: Hours debugging phantom bugs

The fix: Git worktrees. Always.

items.title: How cost explosion happens
items.content:
$10/day: Normal usage
$30/day: "Opus for everything" starts
$100/day: Parallel sessions all Opus
$500/day: Auto-accept + no monitoring

Detection: Check costs DAILY until you have a baseline.

items.title: The Adversarial Calibration Dilemma
items.content:
Too strict: Nothing ships, all criticism
Too lenient: Bad code passes, defeats purpose
Just right: Block security/logic, allow style

Heuristic: If adversarial rejects >30% of implementations, it's too strict.

items.title: UNSOLVED: Optimal tiered model rules
items.content: When exactly should task route to Haiku vs Sonnet vs Opus? No clear formula. Current best practice: heuristics + monitoring + iteration.

items.title: Cost vs Quality vs Speed
items.content:
THE TRILEMMA: Pick two, optimize for constraints
Budget-critical: Accept slower or lower quality
Quality-critical: Accept higher cost or slower
Speed-critical: Accept higher cost or lower quality

No free lunch. Define your constraint first.

items.title: What if coordination was free?
items.content:
You'd run: 100 parallel agents
Why this fails: Coordination tokens > work tokens past ~5 agents
Hidden constraint: Orchestration IS a cost. The optimal team size exists.

items.title: Complexity perception over time
items.content:
Week 1: "This is too complicated"
Month 1: "I understand most failure modes"
Month 3: "It's just infrastructure now"
Month 6: "I forget I'm using a stack"

Complexity becomes invisible through familiarity.

items.title: Steve Yegge: "The coordination tax"
items.content: Gas Town creator on multi-agent complexity: "Every agent you add doubles coordination overhead. The math catches up fast." Solution: Specialized workers with clear boundaries.

items.title: What if you used triple+ for a weekend project?
items.content:
You'd spend: 2 days setting up, 0 days building
Why this fails: Stack ROI requires 4+ weeks to materialize
Hidden insight: Small projects should use NO stack, just Claude.

items.title: At $300/month, hiring math changes
items.content: Solo developer + triple+ stack = small team output at $300/month. This changes the economics of hiring contractors, expanding teams, and project planning.

items.title: Consultant + Quality Obsessed + Budget
items.content:
Works: Opus for client-facing code, Haiku for internal tooling. Quality where it matters, cost control elsewhere.
Danger: Scope creep - client work expands into "Opus everything"
Fix: Hard rules: client modules = Opus, internal = Haiku.

items.title: If triple+ isn't right for you
items.content:
New to Claude Code? -> Master single patterns first
Small project? -> Just Ralph or just Hooks
Exploratory work? -> Single Claude session
Budget-critical? -> Budget Maximalist only
Need results this week? -> Skip stack, ship vanilla

items.title: Molly Cantillon: Jmail with 18M users
items.content: Built overnight with Ralph loops. "The stack paid for itself in the first feature. Now it's just how we build." Proof that triple+ works at real scale.
